tn.text: John begins to describe his vision of the new Jerusalem.
Here "I" refers to John.

tn.ref: like a bride adorned for her husband
tn.text: This compares the new Jerusalem to a bride, who makes herself beautiful for her bridegroom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: a great voice from the throne saying
tn.text: The word "voice" refers to the one who speaks. AT: "someone speak loudly from the throne saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "Look" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.

tn.ref: The dwelling place of God is with human beings, and he will live with them
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that God will, indeed, live among men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: He will wipe away every tear from their eyes
tn.text: Tears here represent sadness. AT: "God will wipe away their sadness, like wiping away tears" or "God will cause them to not be sad anymore." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:07:15|7:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: these words are trustworthy and true
tn.text: Here "words" refers to the message that they formed. AT: "this message is trustworthy and true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the alpha and the omega, the beginning and the end
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize God's eternal nature. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]]).

These are first and last letters of the Greek alphabet. Possible meanings are 1) "the one who began all things and who ends all things" or 2) "the one who has always lived and who always will live". If unclear to readers you may consider using the first and last letters of your alphabet. AT: "the A and the Z" or "the first and the last." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:01:07|1:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Possible meanings are 1) "the one who began all things and the one who will cause all things to end" (UDB) or 2) "the one who existed before all things and who will exist after all things."

tn.ref: To the one who thirsts ... water of life
tn.text: God speaks of a person's desire for eternal life as if it were thirst and of that person receiving eternal life as if he were drinking life-giving water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The one seated on the throne continues to speak to John.
"those who are too afraid to do what is right"
"those who do terrible things"

tn.ref: the fiery lake of burning sulfur
tn.text: "the lake of fire that burns with sulfur" (UDB) or "place full of fire that burns with sulfur." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:19:19|19:20]].

"dying a second time." This is described as eternal punishment in the lake of fire in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:20:13|20:14]] and [[:en:bible:notes:rev:21:07|21:08]]. AT: "the final death in the lake of fire." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:02:10|2:11]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])

tn.ref: the bride, the wife of the Lamb
tn.text: The angel speaks of Jerusalem as if it were a woman who is about to marry her groom, the Lamb. Jerusalem is metonymy for those who believers who will inhabit it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a young male sheep. Here is it used symbolically to refer to Christ. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:05:06|5:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])

tn.ref: carried me away in the Spirit
tn.text: The setting changes as John is taken to a high mountain where he can see the city of Jerusalem. See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:17:03|17:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This refers to the "Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven" that he described in the previous verse and not to the physical Jerusalem.

tn.ref: like a very precious jewel, like a stone of crystal-clear jasper
tn.text: clear jasper** - These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the brilliance of Jerusalem by naming a specific jewel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
clear** - "extremely clear"
This is a valuable stone. Jasper may have been clear like glass or crystal. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:04:01|4:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"12 gates" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone had written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to Jesus. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:05:06|5:6]].
A stadium measures 185 meters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A cubit measures 46 centimeters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: The wall was built of jasper and the city of pure gold
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone had built the wall with jasper and the city with pure gold" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The gold was so clear that it is spoken of as if it was glass. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: The foundations of the wall were adorned
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone adorned the foundations of the wall" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

These are valuable stones. Jasper may have been clear like glass or crystal, and carnelian may have been red. Emeralds are green. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:04:01|4:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: sapphire ... agate ... onyx ... chrysolite ... beryl ... topaz ... chrysoprase ... jacinth ... amethyst
tn.text: These are all precious gems. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

beautiful and valuable white beads. They are formed inside the shell of a certain kind of small animal that lives in the ocean. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:17:03|17:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: each of the gates was made from a single pearl
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone had made each of the gates from a single pearl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The gold was so clear that it is spoken of as if it was glass. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:21:18|21:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Lord God ... and the Lamb are its temple
tn.text: The temple represented God's presence. This means the new Jerusalem does not need a temple because God and the Lamb will live there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here the glory of Jesus, the Lamb, is spoken of as if it were a lamp that gives light to the city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Its gates will not be shut
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "No one will shut the gates" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"The kings of the earth will bring"
These two negative words can be expressed in a positive way by saying "only what is clean will ever enter." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: but only those whose names are written in the Lamb's Book of Life
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but only those whose names the Lamb wrote in his Book of Life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a young male sheep. Here is it used symbolically to refer to Christ. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:05:06|5:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
